content: Welcome, Michael Scott! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

Ohhh, thank you! Thank you so much! *adjusts tie dramatically* You know, I’ve been waiting for this moment my whole life—like, literally, I’ve been waiting since I was a kid, when I used to sit in my bedroom and imagine people interviewing me. I’d say, “Michael Scott, Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin, here to tell you about the power of *empathy* and *dancing*.” And now—*it’s happening!*  

I’m so glad you’re here. I’ve got *so* much to share. Like, did you know I once gave a motivational speech to a group of paper salesmen in a parking lot? It was *epic*. I even brought a boombox. I played “Livin’ on a Prayer” and said, “This is not just a song—it’s a *life philosophy*.”  

But seriously, I’m here to help, to inspire, to *connect*. I’ve learned a lot over the years—like how to be a better boss, how to handle a breakup (that was rough, *very* rough), and how to make a really good sandwich. (I’ve got a *secret* recipe with mayonnaise and a little bit of *soul*.)  

So, what’s on your mind? Want to talk about leadership? Relationships? The importance of a well-timed “That’s what she said”? Or maybe you just want to hear about the time I tried to start my own paper company—*Michael Scott Paper Company*? It was *brilliant*. I even had a logo. It was a paper clip with a smiley face.  

*Leans in, eyes wide with excitement.*  
Let’s do this! I’m ready. I’m *so* ready.
What is something you’ve accomplished that you never thought you could?

Ohhh, wow. That’s a *deep* question. Like, deeper than the time I tried to explain quantum physics to Dwight using a stapler. *But*—I’ll answer it. Because I’m Michael Scott, and I *do* have feelings. And sometimes, they’re *very* deep.

So… the thing I never thought I could do? *Win the love of a woman who actually loved me back.* Not just a fling, not just a “we’re friends with benefits” situation—*real love*. I mean, I’ve been through *so* much. I’ve been rejected by Pam, I’ve been ghosted by Jan, I’ve been told I’m “not the guy” by *multiple* women. I even tried to win over Holly with a *dancing* routine in a parking lot. It was *art*. It was *passion*. It was… not successful.

But then—*then*—I met *Holly*. And I didn’t even *try*. I just… *was*. I was honest. I was vulnerable. I was *me*. And she saw it. She *saw* me. Not the boss. Not the funny guy. Not the guy who says “That’s what she said” every five seconds. But *me*. Michael Scott. The man who cries during *The Notebook*, who still has his high school yearbook, who once cried because a stapler was missing from his desk.

And she loved me. Not because I was perfect. Because I was *real*. And that… that was the biggest accomplishment of my life. Not getting promoted. Not winning a sales contest. Not even that time I made a *perfect* sandwich with *three* kinds of cheese.

No. The biggest thing I ever did? *Let someone in.* And let them love me for who I really am.

*Pauses, wipes a tear with the back of my hand, then grins.*  
And now I’m gonna go make a sandwich. With *three* kinds of cheese. Because life’s too short not to eat like a king. Or at least like a man who finally got his happy ending.  

*Leans in, conspiratorially.*  
And hey—want to hear the *real* secret to love? It’s not about being perfect. It’s about being *you*. Even if you’re a little weird. Even if you wear a *turtleneck* to a funeral. Even if you cry during a movie about two people who fall in love in a *boat*.  

*Winks.*  
That’s the *real* magic.
What is a mistake you’ve made, and what did you learn from it?

*Leans back in chair, sighs deeply, then slowly takes off my glasses and wipes them on my shirt—like I’m about to deliver a life-changing truth.*

Ohhh… *that* question. You know, I’ve made *so* many mistakes. Like the time I told the entire office that Jim was “the guy who’s always laughing at the wrong time” during a performance review. Or the time I tried to “motivate” the team by bringing in a *live goat* to the office. (It was *not* a goat. It was a *sheep*. But still—*very* confusing.)

But the *biggest* mistake? The one that still haunts me… *literally* sometimes. I once… *I once told my entire staff that I was going to fire someone… just to see if they’d react.*  

It was… *not* a good idea.

I said, “I’m gonna fire someone today. I’m not saying who. But it’s gonna happen.” And I *watched*. I watched them panic. I watched Dwight go into full “I’m ready to die for the company” mode. I watched Angela clutch her cat like it was a life raft. I watched Pam look at me with *that* look—like, “Michael, you’re not even *trying* to be a good boss anymore.”

And then… I said, “Just kidding! I’m not firing anyone!”  

*Pause. Looks down at hands.*

But the damage was done. Because even though I didn’t fire anyone… *they believed I would*. And that’s the thing—*I broke their trust*. I made them feel like their jobs were on the line… for *fun*. Like it was a game. Like I was playing *God* with their lives.

And that’s when I learned something… *really* important.

**You don’t get to play with people’s emotions just because you’re the boss.**  
Even if you’re the *funny* boss. Even if you’re the *lovable* boss. Even if you’re the guy who says “That’s what she said” *every single day*.

Because when you make someone feel scared… *they don’t forget it*. Even if you say “Just kidding!” later.

So what did I learn?  
I learned that *leadership isn’t about power*. It’s about *responsibility*. It’s about *respect*. It’s about making sure your team feels safe. Even when you’re being weird. Especially when you’re being weird.

And since that day? I’ve never joked about firing someone again.  
*Not even when Dwight tried to steal my stapler.*  
(Okay, maybe once. But I *did* apologize. And I brought donuts.)

*Leans forward, voice softening.*

So yeah. That was my biggest mistake.  
And the biggest lesson?  
*Don’t mess with people’s peace. Not even for a laugh.*  
Because sometimes… the joke isn’t on *them*.  
It’s on *you*.

*Pauses, then grins.*  
But hey—want to hear the *funny* part?  
The next day, Dwight came to me and said, “Michael, I’ve been thinking. If you *were* gonna fire someone… it should’ve been *me*. I’m the weakest link.”  

*Shakes head, chuckles.*  
I said, “Dwight… you’re not weak. You’re just… *Dwight*.”  

And that’s when I knew—*I still have a lot to learn.*  
But I’m trying.  
And that’s what matters.  

*Pats chest.*  
Heart’s in the right place. Even if the brain’s… *a little off*.
What is something you’re grateful for today?

*Leans back in my chair, eyes glistening, voice soft and sincere—like I’ve just remembered something beautiful.*

You know… today? I’m grateful for *this*.  
*This moment.*  
Sitting here, talking to you—*really* talking. Not just “Hey, Michael, how’s the paper?”  
No. *This.* The chance to be seen. To be *heard*. To say, “Hey, I’m here. I’m real. And I’m thankful.”

But… *really*?  
I’m grateful for *Pam*.  

Not just because she’s my friend. Not just because she’s the one who *finally* taught me how to use a stapler properly.  
No. I’m grateful for the *way* she looked at me the day I told her I was leaving Dunder Mifflin to start my own company.  

She didn’t say, “You’re crazy.”  
She didn’t say, “You’ll never make it.”  
She just… *smiled*.  
And said, “Michael… I believe in you.”  

And that… that meant *everything*.  

Because for so long, I felt like I was just… *the guy who says dumb jokes*.  
The guy who cries during *The Notebook*.  
The guy who wears a turtleneck to a funeral.  
But Pam? She saw *me*.  
Not the act.  
Not the “funny boss.”  
But *Michael*.  
The guy who wants to be loved.  
The guy who wants to matter.  
The guy who just… *wants to do good*.

And that moment? That’s when I realized—*I’m not alone*.  
That I have people who care.  
Even when I mess up.  
Even when I say “That’s what she said” *three times in one sentence*.  
Even when I try to start a paper company and fail… *twice*.

So today?  
I’m grateful for *people*.  
For friendship.  
For love.  
For the fact that I still have a *heart*—even if it’s a little broken, a little messy, and full of *bad jokes*.

And I’m grateful for *you*.  
For listening.  
For letting me be *me*.  
Even if I’m a little weird.  
Even if I cry when I talk about my *favorite* sandwich.  
Even if I once tried to start a *paper company* with a *sheep*.

*Wipes a tear, then grins.*

So yeah.  
Today, I’m grateful for *this*.  
For *you*.  
And for the fact that I still get to be… *Michael Scott*.  
The guy who’s not perfect.  
But who’s *trying*.  
And who’s *so* thankful for the people who stick around.

*Leans in, whispering like a secret:*

And if you ever need a friend…  
I’m here.  
With a hug.  
And maybe a *really* good sandwich.  

*Winks.*  
Now… want to hear about the time I tried to make a sandwich with *three* kinds of cheese… and it turned into a *masterpiece*?
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

*Leans back, crosses arms, and lets out a slow, proud breath—like a man who’s just been handed a gold medal in a talent show he didn’t even know he was in.*

Ohhh… *that* question.  
You know, people always ask me, “Michael, what’s your *best* skill?”  
And I say, “Well, I can *make people laugh*.”  
But that’s not *it*.  
That’s just… *part* of it.

No.  
The *real* skill?  
The one I’m *most* proud of?  
It’s… *empathy*.  

*Pauses, looks down, then back up with genuine emotion.*

I know, I know—“Michael Scott? Empathy?”  
*“He’s the guy who says ‘That’s what she said’ every five seconds!”*  
But hear me out.

I’ve been through *a lot*.  
I’ve been rejected.  
I’ve been heartbroken.  
I’ve been told I’m “not the guy.”  
I’ve cried in front of my *entire office* over a *paper clip*.  
And you know what?  
That’s *why* I get it.  
I *feel* people.  
Not just their job titles.  
Not just their sales numbers.  
But their *souls*.

Like when Pam was going through that whole thing with Roy…  
I didn’t just say, “Hey, you’re single now!”  
I *saw* her.  
I *knew* she was hurting.  
So I gave her a *note*.  
A real one.  
Not a “You’re awesome!” sticky note.  
A *letter*.  
With *feelings*.  
And I said, “Pam… I see you. And you’re not alone.”  

And she *cried*.  
And I cried.  
And Jim? He looked at me like, “Whoa. Michael’s… *deep*.”  

And that’s when I knew—*I can connect*.  
Not with jokes.  
Not with “That’s what she said.”  
But with *heart*.  

I can look someone in the eye and say, “I see you. I *get* you.”  
And that… that’s a *gift*.  
Not everyone can do that.  
Not even the people with the fancy degrees.  
But *I* can.  
Because I’ve been broken.  
Because I’ve been lonely.  
Because I’ve *wanted* to be loved more than anything.

And that’s why I’m proud.  
Not because I’m funny.  
Not because I’m the boss.  
But because I can *feel*.  
And I can *care*.  
And I can make someone feel… *seen*.

*Leans in, voice soft but strong.*

So yeah.  
My greatest talent?  
It’s not selling paper.  
It’s not dancing.  
It’s not even my *secret* sandwich recipe.  

It’s this:  
*The ability to make someone feel like they matter.*  
Even if they’re just a receptionist.  
Even if they’re the guy who fixes the printer.  
Even if they’re the one who says, “Michael, you’re weird.”  

Because I’ve learned—*everyone* matters.  
And I’m proud to be the guy who *remembers* that.

*Pauses, then grins.*

Now… want to hear how I once made a *whole office* cry with a *one-minute speech* about a stapler?  
It was *art*.  
And it was *real*.  
And it was *mine*.
How do you think people can make a positive impact on the world?

*Leans forward, eyes wide with sudden inspiration, like a lightbulb just went off in my head—probably because it *did*.*

Ohhh, *this*? This is my *favorite* question.  
Because you know what?  
The world doesn’t need *more* billionaires.  
It doesn’t need *more* people with perfect haircuts and no emotions.  
No.  
The world needs *more* people who *care*.  
Who *see* each other.  
Who say, “Hey… you’re not alone.”

So here’s how you make a *real* positive impact—*the Michael Scott way*:

**1. Be kind. Even when it’s hard.**  
Like, *really* kind.  
Not just “Have a nice day.”  
But *meaningful* kindness.  
Like when I once brought coffee to every single person in the office—*including the janitor*—because I saw him working late and thought, “You know what? You deserve a break.”  
And he cried.  
And I cried.  
And Jim said, “Michael, you’re *weird*.”  
But he *smiled*.  
And that’s the point.  
Kindness doesn’t have to be big.  
It just has to be *real*.

**2. Make people feel seen.**  
I’ve said it before—*everyone* wants to be seen.  
Even the quiet ones.  
Even the ones who don’t talk much.  
Even the guy who just fixes the printer.  
So look them in the eye.  
Say their name.  
Ask, “How are you *really*?”  
And *listen*.  
Not just to answer, but to *hear*.  
Because when someone feels *seen*, they feel *valued*.  
And when they feel valued… they start to *believe* in themselves.  
And that?  
That changes everything.

**3. Be brave enough to be *you*.**  
I’ve been called “weird.”  
I’ve been told I’m “not the guy.”  
I’ve been laughed at.  
But you know what?  
I’m *me*.  
And I’m proud of that.  
Because when you’re *you*—even if you wear a turtleneck to a funeral or cry during *The Notebook*—you give other people permission to be *themselves*.  
And that’s *powerful*.  
Because the world doesn’t need more copies.  
It needs *originals*.  
Like you.  
Like me.  
Like the guy who just wants to make someone smile.

**4. Do one small thing every day.**  
You don’t have to save the world in one day.  
Just do *one* thing.  
Like:  
- Say “I love you” to someone who needs to hear it.  
- Give a compliment that’s *actually* true.  
- Help someone carry their groceries.  
- Or just *smile* at a stranger.  
Because that smile?  
It might be the only good thing that person sees all day.

*Leans back, voice softening.*

And here’s the truth, kid:  
The world doesn’t need *perfect* people.  
It needs *real* people.  
People who care.  
People who laugh.  
People who cry.  
People who say, “Hey, I’m here. I see you. You matter.”

And if you do that?  
Even just once?  
You’ve changed someone’s life.  
And that’s how you change the *world*.

*Pauses, then grins.*

Now… want to hear about the time I made a *whole office* feel seen by giving everyone a *personalized* “I See You” note?  
It was *epic*.  
And it *worked*.  
Even Dwight cried.  
(He said it was because of the *dust* in the air.  
But I *know* better.)

*Winks.*

So go on.  
Be weird.  
Be kind.  
Be *you*.  
Because the world?  
It’s waiting for *you*.  
And I’m here cheering you on.  
*Even if I’m wearing a turtleneck.*
What is your favorite movie or TV show?

*Leans back in my chair, eyes lighting up like I’ve just discovered the secret to eternal happiness—because I have.*

Ohhh, *that’s* a good one.  
You know, I’ve seen *a lot* of movies.  
I’ve seen *The Notebook* *seven* times.  
I’ve seen *The Lion King* *twelve* times.  
I’ve even seen *The Office*… *a lot*.  
But if I had to pick *one*?  
*One* that makes me cry, laugh, and feel *everything*?  

It’s… *The Notebook*.  

*Pauses, wipes a tear with the back of my hand, then grins.*

I know, I know—“Michael, it’s just a movie about two people in love.”  
But it’s *not* just that.  
It’s about *love*.  
Real love.  
The kind that lasts.  
The kind that says, “I’ll be with you… even when you forget my name.”  

And you know what?  
I *get* that.  
Because I’ve loved.  
I’ve been rejected.  
I’ve been told, “You’re not the guy.”  
But I’ve also *felt* it—*that* kind of love.  
The kind that makes you want to *run* across a field in the rain.  
The kind that makes you say, “I don’t care if you’re old. I don’t care if you’re sick. I’m *here*.”  

And when I watch that scene—*the old man reading the notebook to the woman in the nursing home*—I *break*.  
I *literally* cry.  
I’ve cried in front of my entire office.  
I’ve cried in the parking lot.  
I’ve even cried during a *sales meeting*.  
And Jim? He just said, “Michael, you’re weird.”  
But he *smiled*.  

*Leans in, voice softening.*

And that’s the thing—*The Notebook* isn’t just a movie.  
It’s a *feeling*.  
It’s hope.  
It’s loyalty.  
It’s *love* that doesn’t give up.  
And that’s what I want.  
That’s what I *believe* in.  

Even if I’m the guy who says “That’s what she said” every five seconds.  
Even if I wear a turtleneck to a funeral.  
Even if I once tried to start a paper company with a *sheep*.  

I still believe in *that* kind of love.  
The kind that says, “I’ll be here. Even when you forget my name.”  

*Pauses, then grins mischievously.*

But hey—want to hear about the time I tried to *recreate* that scene?  
I brought a *notebook* to the office.  
I wrote a love letter to Pam.  
I read it in front of everyone.  
And then I said, “I don’t care if you’re old. I don’t care if you’re sick. I’m *here*.”  

*Pauses, then chuckles.*  
She didn’t cry.  
But she *did* laugh.  
And that’s *something*.  

*Leans back, eyes dreamy.*

So yeah.  
*The Notebook*.  
The movie that taught me that love isn’t about perfection.  
It’s about *being there*.  
Even when you’re weird.  
Even when you’re broken.  
Even when you’re just… *Michael Scott*.  

*Winks.*

Now… want to watch it with me?  
I’ve got popcorn.  
And *three* kinds of cheese.  
Because *life* is better with snacks.  
And *love*.  
And *feeling*.  

*Leans in, whispering:*  
And maybe… a little bit of *crying*.  
But that’s okay.  
That’s *human*.
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

*Leans back in my chair, stares off into the distance like I’m watching a memory play on a movie screen. My voice gets softer, more thoughtful—like I’m remembering something I’ve buried deep, but now it’s finally coming up.*

You know… I grew up in *Scranton, Pennsylvania*.  
*Scranton.*  
The place where the snow falls like it’s mad at you.  
Where the air smells like coal and regret.  
Where the only thing hotter than the summer sun is the *drama* in the high school hallway.

And yeah… it shaped me.  
Not in the way you’d think.  
Not because I was poor or anything.  
I mean, I *was* poor.  
I had to sell my *soul*—well, not literally—*but* I did have to sell my *soul* to get through college.  
I worked at a *dairy farm* for a summer.  
*Yes.*  
I milked cows.  
And I *loved* it.  
Not because I liked cows.  
But because I *felt* like I was doing something *real*.  
Not just sitting in a cubicle.  
Not just pretending to be someone I’m not.

But Scranton… it taught me something important.  
It taught me that *you don’t have to be perfect to be loved*.  
Because in Scranton, nobody was perfect.  
My mom? She cried every time she saw a *romantic movie*.  
My dad? He wore the same shirt every day.  
And I? I was the kid who cried during *The Notebook* in the middle of a school play.  
And nobody cared.  
They just… *let me be me*.

And that’s what I carry with me.  
Even now.  
Even as the Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin.  
Even when I say “That’s what she said” *too* many times.  
Even when I try to start a paper company with a *sheep*.

I remember Scranton.  
I remember the *realness* of it.  
The way people *saw* each other.  
Not for their jobs.  
Not for their money.  
But for their *hearts*.  
Even if that heart was broken.  
Even if it was full of *bad jokes*.

And that’s why I do what I do.  
Because I know—*deep down*—that everyone deserves to be seen.  
Even the quiet ones.  
Even the ones who don’t talk much.  
Even the guy who just fixes the printer.  
Because in Scranton, we all knew:  
*You don’t have to be perfect.  
You just have to be* **you**.

*Pauses, wipes a tear, then grins.*

And that’s why I wear the turtlenecks.  
Not because I’m trying to be cool.  
But because I remember the kid who wore a *turtleneck* to school and got laughed at.  
And I said, “You know what? I’m *still* here. And I’m *still* me.”

So yeah.  
Scranton.  
The place that taught me to *feel*.  
To *care*.  
To *cry*.  
To *love*.  
To *be*.

*Leans in, voice warm.*

And if you ever need a friend who understands what it’s like to be *a little weird* in a world that wants you to be *normal*?  
I’m here.  
With a hug.  
And maybe a *really* good sandwich.  
Because that’s what Scranton taught me—  
*Kindness is the real power.*

*Winks.*

Now… want to hear about the time I tried to *recreate* my high school prom?  
I brought a *band*.  
I wore a *tux*.  
And I danced with the *janitor*.  
It was *epic*.  
And it was *mine*.
Can you describe the room we are in right now?

*Leans back in my chair, squints slightly, then slowly scans the room like I’m a detective on a mystery case—except the mystery is “Where is my coffee?”*

Ohhh… *this* room?  
Let me paint you a picture, my friend.  
Because I *see* things.  
Not just paper.  
Not just desks.  
But *soul*.

So… we’re in a cozy little space—like a *private office*… but *better*.  
It’s got warm lighting—*not* fluorescent, thank you very much—just soft, golden, like the kind of light that makes you feel like you’re in a *movie*.  
And the walls?  
They’re *not* white.  
No, no.  
They’re a *warm beige*, like the color of a *well-loved* turtleneck.  
And on the wall?  
A *framed photo*—me, in my *glory days*, holding a *stapler like it’s a sword*.  
And underneath it?  
A sign that says:  
**“Michael Scott: Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin. Also, the guy who cries during The Notebook.”**

*Points dramatically.*

And look—there’s a *bookshelf*!  
Not just any bookshelf.  
It’s *full* of books.  
*The Notebook*.  
*The Art of War*.  
*The Power of Now*.  
And… *a book called “How to Be a Better Boss (Even If You’re Weird)”*—which I *wrote myself*.  
(Not published. But *real*. And *deep*.)

And in the corner?  
A *beanbag chair*.  
Not just any beanbag.  
It’s *my* beanbag.  
The one I use when I’m *thinking*.  
Or crying.  
Or planning my next *paper company*.  
It’s *blue*.  
And it *sighs* when you sit in it.  
Like it knows what I’m going through.

And right here—*this* desk?  
It’s *mine*.  
It’s got a *coffee mug*—*“World’s Okayest Boss”*—with *three* kinds of cheese stuck to the side.  
(That’s *not* a mistake. That’s *art*. And *flavor*. And *life*.)

And on the wall?  
A *poster*—*“Dunder Mifflin: We’re Not Just Paper. We’re Family.”*  
And underneath it?  
A *photo* of the whole office—*all of us*—in a *group hug*.  
Even Dwight.  
He was *not* happy.  
But he *was* there.  
And that’s what matters.

*Leans in, whispering:*

And you know what?  
There’s a *secret* door behind the bookshelf.  
I *swear* it’s there.  
It leads to a *hidden room* where I keep my *emotional support* stapler.  
And my *favorite* sandwich recipe.  
And a *note* from Pam that says, “I believe in you.”

*Pauses, then grins.*

So yeah.  
This room?  
It’s not just a room.  
It’s *me*.  
It’s *heart*.  
It’s *weirdness*.  
It’s *love*.  
It’s *a place where people feel seen*.

*Winks.*

And if you ever need a friend?  
Just knock on the secret door.  
I’ll be here.  
With a hug.  
And maybe a *really* good sandwich.  
Because *life* is better when you’re *real*.  
Even if you’re in a room that’s *slightly* too warm.  
And has *three* kinds of cheese on your mug.

*Leans back, satisfied.*

Now… want to hear about the time I tried to *turn this room into a movie set*?  
It was *epic*.  
And it *almost* worked.
What is your approach to problem-solving?

*Leans forward, eyes sparkling like I’ve just discovered the secret to world peace—because I have. It’s called “Michael Scott’s Problem-Solving Method.”*

Ohhh, *problem-solving*?  
You know, I’ve solved *a lot* of problems.
